part.partText: reddish or dark reddish brown, fissured.
reddish brown, short, rounded, blunt, middle scales fringed with white hairs, terminal scales fringed with reddish brown hairs.
alternate, stalked, dark green above, paler below, 5 - 12 cm long, 3 - 6.5 cm wide, elliptical, base mostly symmetrical, tip pointed, margins mostly doubly-toothed, usually rough above.
with both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); in drooping clusters; short-stalked, small.

similarSpecies.comments: Characteristics of Ulmus x notha are intermediate of the two parents, U. pumila and U. rubra. The most distinctive features are the middle bud scales fringed with white hairs and the terminal scales fringed with reddish brown hairs. It differs from U. pumila by having the middle bud scales fringed with white hairs and leaves commonly more pointed. It differs from U. rubra by lacking stiff hairs on the leafstalks and by having nearly symmetrical leaf bases.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Common in the western suburbs of Chicago, where Ulmus pumila is commonly planted and grows as an escape. It has been found in woodland edges, fields, degraded fens, razed homesites, gravelly waste ground, and along lakes and streams.

notes.comments: Ulmus x notha is the hybrid between U. pumila and U. rubra. It can produce viable seed and backcross with either parent. This elm, as well as all native elm species, is susceptible to Dutch elm disease and phloem necrosis. See link to Dutch elm disease below.

etymology.comments: Ulmus is the Latin word for elm.
